Problem:
Consider a system described by the linear differential equation \\(dz/dt = Mz\\), where M represents a square matrix. We explore the consequence of applying a Fourier transform \\( F(z) = \\int e^{-i\\omega t}z(t) dt \\) at some initial condition and examine its impact on system dynamics.

Suppose at time \\( t_1 \\), an intervention via an inverse Fourier transform \\( F^{-1}(z) = \\int e^{i\\omega t}z(\\omega) d\\omega \\) is applied. Will the system state \\( z(T) \\) for T > t_1 depend exclusively on matrix M, disregarding any earlier effect from the initial Fourier transform?
Explanation: The inverse transform reconstitutes the state back into the time domain potentially with changes due to initial Fourier transform. Hence, the state at \\( z(T) \\) is shaped by both the initial Fourier transformation and its inverse, alongside the influence of matrix M.
